Semi-Decentralized Federated Edge Learning for Fast Convergence on Non-IID Data

Yuchang Sun∗, Jiawei Shao∗, Yuyi Mao†, Jessie Hui Wang‡, and Jun Zhang∗ ∗Dept. of ECE, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong
†Dept. of EIE, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong
‡Institute for Network Sciences and Cyberspace, BNRist, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Email: {yuchang.sun, jiawei.shao}@connect.ust.hk, yuyi-eie.mao@polyu.edu.hk,
jessiewang@tsinghua.edu.cn, eejzhang@ust.hk
Abstract

Federated edge learning (FEEL) has emerged as an effective approach to reduce the large communication latency in Cloud-based machine learning solutions, while preserving data privacy. Unfortunately, the learning performance of FEEL may be compromised due to limited training data in a single edge cluster. In this paper, we investigate a novel framework of FEEL, namely semi-decentralized federated edge learning (SD-FEEL). By allowing model aggregation across different edge clusters, SD-FEEL enjoys the benefit of FEEL in reducing the training latency, while improving the learning performance by accessing richer training data from multiple edge clusters. A training algorithm for SD-FEEL with three main procedures in each round is presented, including local model updates, intra-cluster and inter-cluster model aggregations, which is proved to converge on non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data. We also characterize the interplay between the network topology of the edge servers and the communication overhead of inter-cluster model aggregation on the training performance. Experiment results corroborate our analysis and demonstrate the effectiveness of SD-FFEL in achieving faster convergence than traditional federated learning architectures. Besides, guidelines on choosing critical hyper-parameters of the training algorithm are also provided.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, non-IID data, distributed machine learning, communication efficiency.

I Introduction

The recent development of machine learning (ML) technologies has led to major breakthroughs in various domains. Meanwhile, the number of Internet of Things (IoT) devices is growing at a drastic speed, and it is envisaged to reach more than 30 billion IoT devices by 2025 [1]. This results in a huge volume of data generated at the edge of the wireless network, which will facilitate the training of powerful ML models. A traditional approach is to upload these data to a centralized server for model training. However, offloading data raises severe privacy concerns as data collected by IoT devices, e.g., smartphones and healthcare sensors, may contain privacy-sensitive information [2].

To resolve the privacy issues in centralized ML, federated learning (FL) was proposed by Google in 2017 as a privacy-preserving distributed ML paradigm [3]. FL enables IoT devices to collaboratively learn a shared ML model without disclosing their local data. A typical FL system consists of a Cloud-based parameter server (PS) and a number of client nodes which train a deep learning (DL) model via multiple global iterations. In each global iteration, the client nodes first download the global model maintained by the PS, based on which several rounds of local updates are performed using the private local data. The updated local models are then transmitted to the PS for global model aggregation. Nevertheless, as DL models, typically with millions of parameters, need to be uploaded to the Cloud in every global iteration, the communication latency caused by core-network congestion significantly bottlenecks the learning efficiency [4], [5].

Attributed to the emergence of mobile edge computing (MEC) [6], federated edge learning (FEEL), where an edge server located in close proximity to the client nodes (e.g., a base station) is deployed as the PS, was proposed as a promising alternative to Cloud-based FL [7]. Despite its great promise in reducing model uploading latency, one of the major challenges in FEEL systems is the unstable wireless connections between the client nodes and the edge server, and client nodes with unfavorable channel conditions may become stragglers for model aggregation and in turn slow down the training process. As a result, improving the training efficiency of FEEL has drawn great interests in existing literature. Considering the limited resources, a control algorithm to determine the global model aggregation frequency of FEEL was developed in [8] to maximize the learning performance. In order to reduce the training time, a client selection algorithm was proposed for FEEL in [9], which eliminates the straggling client nodes from global model aggregation. Besides, gradient quantization and sparsification techniques were also adopted to achieve communication-efficient FEEL [10], [11]. However, the number of accessible client nodes of a single edge server is generally limited, which hinders the benefits of FL due to the small amount of training data.

To unleash the full potential of FEEL, recent works exploited cooperation among multiple edge servers for model training. In [12], a client-edge-cloud hierarchical FL system along with a training algorithm, namely HierFAVG, was developed, which takes advantages of the Cloud and edge servers to accelerate model training. Similar investigations in [13] extended HierFAVG to a multi-level stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm. Besides, a fog-assisted FL framework was proposed in [14], where the Cloud-based PS selects an optimal fog node to serve as the global model aggregator in each communication round. Unfortunately, these works still rely on the connection to the Cloud, which may suffer from excessive communication latency. Besides, such architectures are vulnerable to the single-point failure and not scalable to large-scale deployment.

In this paper, we investigate a novel FL architecture, namely semi-decentralized federated edge learning (SD-FEEL), to improve the training efficiency. This architecture is motivated by the low communication latency between edge servers so that efficient model exchanges can be realized. Specifically, we consider multiple edge servers, and each of them coordinates a cluster of client nodes to perform local model updating and intra-cluster model aggregation. The edge servers periodically share their updated models to the neighboring edge servers for inter-cluster model aggregation. Such a semi-decentralized training protocol can accelerate the learning process since a large number of client nodes can collaborate with low communication cost. It is worthy mentioning that a similar design was investigated in [15], which, however, was limited to an idealized independent and identically distributed (IID) assumption of the local training data. Our work in this paper advances SD-FEEL in the following aspects:

  • •

    We extend SD-FEEL to the case with non-IID data. To investigate impacts of the network topology on learning performance, the edge servers are allowed to share and aggregate models multiple times in each round of inter-cluster model aggregation.

  • •

    Convergence of a training algorithm supporting SD-FEEL on non-IID data is proved. Our analysis shows when both intra-cluster and inter-cluster model aggregations are performed at each iteration, SD-FEEL reduces to the vanilla SGD [18] given mutually connected edge servers. This is also achievable by multiple times of inter-server model sharings when the edge servers are only partially connected.

  • •

    Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the benefits of SD-FEEL in achieving faster convergence compared to existing FL schemes. Our results also provide insightful guidelines on choosing the intra-/inter-cluster model aggregation frequencies and the communication strategy among edge servers to reduce the training latency.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the framework of semi-decentralized FEEL. Section III shows the convergence of SD-FEEL on non-IID data and discusses various insights. We present experiment results in Section IV and conclude this paper in Section V.

II Semi-Decentralized FEEL

In this section, we first introduce the semi-decentralized FEEL system, and a training algorithm is then presented.

II-A Semi-Decentralized FEEL System

We consider an edge-assisted federated learning system as shown in Fig. 1, which consists of C𝐶C client nodes (denoted as set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}) and D𝐷D edge servers (denoted as set 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}). Each client node is associated with an edge server according to some pre-defined criteria, e.g., physical proximity and network coverage. We denote the set of client nodes associated with the d𝑑d-th edge server as 𝒞dsubscript𝒞𝑑\mathcal{C}_{d}, which form one edge cluster. Some of the edge servers are inter-connected via high-speed cables, which facilitates information exchange in SD-FEEL. We use a connected graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} to model the connectivity among the edge servers, and denote the one-hop neighbors of the d𝑑d-th edge server as 𝒩dsubscript𝒩𝑑\mathcal{N}_{d}.

Each client node is assumed to have a set of local training data, denoted as 𝒮i={𝒙j,yj}j=1|𝒮i|,i∈𝒞formulae-sequencesubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗𝑗1subscript𝒮𝑖𝑖𝒞\mathcal{S}_{i}=\{\bm{x}_{j},y_{j}\}_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{S}_{i}|},i\in\mathcal{C}, where 𝒙jsubscript𝒙𝑗\bm{x}_{j} is the data sample and yjsubscript𝑦𝑗y_{j} is the corresponding label. The whole training dataset and the collection of local training data across the client nodes associated with the d𝑑d-th server are denoted as 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and 𝒮~dsubscript~𝒮𝑑\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{d}, respectively. The client nodes collaborate to train a shared DL model, denoted as 𝒘∈ℝM𝒘superscriptℝ𝑀\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} with M𝑀M as the number of trainable parameters. Let f​(𝒙j,yj;𝒘)𝑓subscript𝒙𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗𝒘f(\bm{x}_{j},y_{j};\bm{w}) be the loss function associated with the data sample (𝒙j,yj)subscript𝒙𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗(\bm{x}_{j},y_{j}) based on the model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}. As a result, the objective of FL is to minimize the loss function over all the training data, i.e.,

min𝒘∈ℝM⁡{F​(𝒘)≜∑i∈𝒞|𝒮i||𝒮|​Fi​(𝒘)},subscript𝒘superscriptℝ𝑀≜𝐹𝒘subscript𝑖𝒞subscript𝒮𝑖𝒮subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\min_{\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}}\left\{F(\bm{w})\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}\frac{|\mathcal{S}_{i}|}{|\mathcal{S}|}F_{i}(\bm{w})\right\}, (1)

where Fi​(𝒘)≜1|𝒮i|​∑j∈𝒮if​(𝒙j,yj;𝒘)≜subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘1subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑖𝑓subscript𝒙𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w})\triangleq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{i}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{i}}f(\bm{x}_{j},y_{j};\bm{w}).

It is important to note that we will not pose the assumption of homogeneous (i.e., IID) data across the client nodes, which is more reflective of real scenarios and also a highly non-trivial extension compared to the existing study [15].

II-B Training Algorithm

Without loss of generality, we assume there are K𝐾K iterations in the training process, which contains three main procedures, including 1) local model update, 2) intra-cluster model aggregation, and 3) inter-cluster model aggregation. While local model updates are performed at the client nodes, the edge servers are in charge of the other two procedures. The periods of intra-cluster and inter-cluster model aggregation, denoted as τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} and τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} respectively, are two critical hyper-parameters in the training algorithm.

II-B1 Local Model Update

In the k𝑘k-th iteration, each client node performs model update with its local data using the mini-batch SGD algorithm according to the following expression:

𝒘k(i)←𝒘k−1(i)−η​g​(𝝃k(i);𝒘k−1(i)),i∈𝒞,formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1𝑖𝜂𝑔superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1𝑖𝑖𝒞\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)}\leftarrow\bm{w}_{k-1}^{(i)}-\eta g(\bm{\xi}_{k}^{(i)};\bm{w}_{k-1}^{(i)}),i\in\mathcal{C}, (2)

where 𝒘k−1(i)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1𝑖\bm{w}_{k-1}^{(i)} is the most updated model available at the i𝑖i-th client node at the start of the k𝑘k-th iteration, g​(𝝃k(i);𝒘k−1(i))𝑔superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1𝑖g(\bm{\xi}_{k}^{(i)};\bm{w}_{k-1}^{(i)}) is the gradient computed on the batch of randomly-sampled local training data 𝝃k(i)superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑘𝑖\bm{\xi}_{k}^{(i)}, and η𝜂\eta denotes the learning rate.

II-B2 Intra-cluster Model Aggregation

In the k𝑘k-th iteration (when k𝑘k is a multiple integer of τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} but not τ1​τ2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2\tau_{1}\tau_{2}), each client node uploads its most updated model to the associated edge server, and the edge server aggregates the received local models according to the following expression:

𝒘~k(d)←∑i∈𝒞d|𝒮i||𝒮~d|​𝒘k(i),d∈𝒟,formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑subscript𝑖subscript𝒞𝑑subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑑superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖𝑑𝒟\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)}\leftarrow\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{d}}\frac{\left|\mathcal{S}_{i}\right|}{\left|\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{d}\right|}\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)},d\in\mathcal{D}, (3)

where 𝒘~k(d)superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)} denotes the intra-cluster aggregated model at the d𝑑d-th edge server. After that, 𝒘~k(d)superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)} is broadcasted to the client nodes 𝒞dsubscript𝒞𝑑\mathcal{C}_{d}, which can be expressed as follows:

𝒘k(i)←𝒘~k(d),i∈𝒞d.formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑𝑖subscript𝒞𝑑\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)}\leftarrow\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)},i\in\mathcal{C}_{d}. (4)

II-B3 Inter-cluster Model Aggregation

In the k𝑘k-th iteration (when k𝑘k is a multiple integer of τ1​τ2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2\tau_{1}\tau_{2}), after intra-cluster model aggregation, each edge server also shares its intra-cluster aggregated model to the one-hop neighbouring edge servers for inter-cluster model aggregation, before sending it back to the client nodes. Each round of inter-cluster model aggregation consists α∈{1,2,…}𝛼12…\alpha\!\in\!\{\!1,\!2,\!\dots\!\} times of model sharing and aggregation, which can be expressed as follows:

𝒘^k,l(d)←∑j∈𝒩d∪{d}pj,d​𝒘^k,l−1(j),l=1,2,…,α,formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑘𝑙𝑑subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑑𝑑subscript𝑝𝑗𝑑superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑘𝑙1𝑗𝑙12…𝛼\hat{\bm{w}}_{k,l}^{(d)}\leftarrow\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{d}\cup\{d\}}p_{j,d}\hat{\bm{w}}_{k,l-1}^{(j)},l=1,2,\dots,\alpha, (5)

where 𝒘^k,0(d)=𝒘~k(d)superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑘0𝑑superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑\hat{\bm{w}}_{k,0}^{(d)}=\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)} is the intra-cluster aggregated model at the d𝑑d-th edge server, and 𝐏≜[pi,j]∈ℝD×D≜𝐏delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗superscriptℝ𝐷𝐷\mathbf{P}\!\triangleq\![p_{i,j}]\in\mathbb{R}^{D\!\times\!D} is termed as the mixing matrix. We choose 𝐏=𝐈−2λ1​(𝐋′)+λD−1​(𝐋′)​𝐋′𝐏𝐈2subscript𝜆1superscript𝐋′subscript𝜆𝐷1superscript𝐋′superscript𝐋′\mathbf{P}=\mathbf{I}-\frac{2}{\lambda_{1}(\mathbf{L}^{\prime})+\lambda_{D-1}(\mathbf{L}^{\prime})}\mathbf{L}^{\prime} so that fast consensus among edge servers can be achieved [16], where 𝐈𝐈\mathbf{I} is the identity matrix, 𝐋′superscript𝐋′\mathbf{L}^{\prime} is the product of the Laplacian matrix of graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and 𝛀=diag(|𝒮||𝒮~1|,,…,|𝒮||𝒮~D|)\mathbf{\Omega}=\mathrm{diag}(\frac{|\mathcal{S}|}{|\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{1}|},,\dots,\frac{|\mathcal{S}|}{|\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{D}|}), and λi​(𝐋′)subscript𝜆𝑖superscript𝐋′\lambda_{i}(\mathbf{L}^{\prime}) denotes the i𝑖i-th largest eigenvalue of matrix 𝐋′superscript𝐋′\mathbf{L}^{\prime}. Once 𝒘^k,α(d)superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑘𝛼𝑑\hat{\bm{w}}_{k,\alpha}^{\left(d\right)} is computed, it updates 𝒘~k(d)superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)} as 𝒘^k,α(d)superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑘𝛼𝑑\hat{\bm{w}}_{k,\alpha}^{(d)}, which is then transmitted to the client nodes in 𝒞dsubscript𝒞𝑑\mathcal{C}_{d}. The training algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1, where K𝐾K is assumed to be an integer multiple of τ1​τ2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2\tau_{1}\tau_{2}.

III Convergence Analysis for SD-FEEL

In this section, we prove the convergence of Algorithm 1, and draw various insights from our analysis.

III-A Assumptions

We make the following assumptions on the loss functions to facilitate the convergence analysis.

Assumption 1.

For all i∈𝒞𝑖𝒞i\in\mathcal{C}, we assume:

  • •

    (Smoothness) The local loss function is L𝐿L-smooth, i.e.,

    ‖∇Fi​(𝒘1)−∇Fi​(𝒘2)‖2≤L​‖𝒘1−𝒘2‖2,∀𝒘1,𝒘2∈ℝM.formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘22𝐿subscriptnormsubscript𝒘1subscript𝒘22for-allsubscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2superscriptℝ𝑀\left\|\nabla\!F_{i}(\!\bm{w}_{1}\!)\!-\!\nabla\!F_{i}(\!\bm{w}_{2}\!)\right\|_{2}\!\leq\!L\!\left\|\bm{w}_{1}\!-\!\bm{w}_{2}\right\|_{2},\!\forall\bm{w}_{1},\!\bm{w}_{2}\!\in\!\!\mathbb{R}^{\!M}\!. (6)
  • •

    (Unbiased and bounded gradient variance) The mini-batch gradient g​(𝝃;𝒘)𝑔𝝃𝒘g\left(\bm{\xi};\bm{w}\right) is unbiased, i.e.,

    𝔼𝝃|𝒘​[g​(𝝃;𝒘)]=∇Fi​(𝒘),∀𝒘∈ℝM,formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼conditional𝝃𝒘delimited-[]𝑔𝝃𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘for-all𝒘superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\xi}|\bm{w}}[g(\bm{\xi};\bm{w})]=\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}),\forall\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}, (7)

    and there exists σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0 such that

    𝔼𝝃|𝒘​[‖g​(𝝃;𝒘)−∇Fi​(𝒘)‖22]≤σ2,∀𝒘∈ℝM.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼conditional𝝃𝒘delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑔𝝃𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘22superscript𝜎2for-all𝒘superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\xi}|\bm{w}}\left[\left\|g(\bm{\xi};\bm{w})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\sigma^{2},\forall\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}. (8)

    (Degree of non-IIDness) There exists κ>0𝜅0\kappa>0 such that

    ‖∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇F​(𝒘)‖2≤κ,∀𝒘∈ℝM.formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇𝐹𝒘2𝜅for-all𝒘superscriptℝ𝑀\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F(\bm{w})\right\|_{2}\leq\kappa,\quad\forall\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}. (9)

When κ=0𝜅0\kappa=0, ∇F​(𝒘)=∇Fi​(𝒘),∀i∈𝒞formulae-sequence∇𝐹𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘for-all𝑖𝒞\nabla F(\bm{w})=\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}),\forall i\in\mathcal{C}, i.e., the assumption in (9) reduces to the case of IID data across the client nodes.

III-B Convergence Analysis

Denote 𝐖k≜[𝒘k(i)]∈ℝM×C≜subscript𝐖𝑘delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑀𝐶\mathbf{W}_{k}\triangleq[\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)}]\in\mathbb{R}^{M\!\times\!C} and 𝐆k≜[g​(𝝃k+1(i);𝒘k(i))]∈ℝM×C≜subscript𝐆𝑘delimited-[]𝑔superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑘1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑀𝐶\mathbf{G}_{k}\triangleq[g(\bm{\xi}_{k+1}^{(i)};\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)})]\in\mathbb{R}^{M\!\times\!C}. Proof.  The proof can be obtained by rewriting (5) as 𝐖^k,l=𝐏​𝐖^k,l−1subscript^𝐖𝑘𝑙𝐏subscript^𝐖𝑘𝑙1\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{k,l}=\mathbf{P}\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{k,l-1} and showing 𝐖^k,α=𝐏α​𝐖^k,0subscript^𝐖𝑘𝛼superscript𝐏𝛼subscript^𝐖𝑘0\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{k,\alpha}=\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{k,0}. For convenience, we define 𝒖k≜∑i∈𝒞mi​𝒘k(i)≜subscript𝒖𝑘subscript𝑖𝒞subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖\bm{u}_{k}\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}m_{i}\bm{w}_{k}^{(i)} where mi≜|𝒮i||𝒮|≜subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖𝒮m_{i}\triangleq\frac{|\mathcal{S}_{i}|}{|\mathcal{S}|}, and ‖𝐗‖𝐌≜∑i=1M∑j=1Nmi,j​|xi,j|2≜subscriptnorm𝐗𝐌superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗2\left\|\mathbf{X}\right\|_{\mathbf{M}}\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sum_{j=1}^{N}m_{i,j}|x_{i,j}|^{2} is the weighted Frobenius norm of an M×N𝑀𝑁M\times N matrix 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Following Lemma 8 in [17] and leveraging the evolution expression of 𝐖ksubscript𝐖𝑘\mathbf{W}_{k} in (10), we bound the expected change of the local loss functions in consecutive iterations as follows:

where 𝐌≜𝒎​𝟏T≜𝐌𝒎superscript1𝑇\mathbf{M}\triangleq\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T} and Jk≜𝔼​[‖∑i∈𝒞mi​∇Fi​(𝒘k(i))‖22]≜subscript𝐽𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑖𝒞subscript𝑚𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑖22J_{k}\!\triangleq\!\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}m_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{k}^{\!(i)})\!\right\|_{\!2}^{\!2}\right]. It remains to bound the last term in the right-hand side (RHS) of (12) in order to show the convergence of Algorithm 1, which can be interpreted as the deviation of the local models from their mean, as shown in Lemma 2.

Lemma 2.

With Assumption 1, we have:

1K​∑k=1K𝔼​[‖𝐖k​(𝐈−𝐌)‖𝐌2]≤8​η2​V2K​∑k=1KJk+2​η2​V1​σ2+8​η2​V2​κ2,1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐖𝑘𝐈𝐌𝐌28superscript𝜂2subscript𝑉2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐽𝑘2superscript𝜂2subscript𝑉1superscript𝜎28superscript𝜂2subscript𝑉2superscript𝜅2\begin{split}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\!\left\|\mathbf{W}_{k}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{M})\right\|_{\mathbf{M}}^{2}\!\right]&\leq\frac{8\eta^{2}V_{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}J_{k}\\ &+2\eta^{2}V_{1}\sigma^{2}+8\eta^{2}V_{2}\kappa^{2},\end{split} (13)

where ζ=|λ2​(𝐏)|∈[0,1)𝜁subscript𝜆2𝐏01\zeta\!=\!|\lambda_{2}(\mathbf{P})|\!\in\![0,1), Λ≜ζ2​α1−ζ2​α+2​ζα1−ζα+ζ2​α(1−ζα)2≜Λsuperscript𝜁2𝛼1superscript𝜁2𝛼2superscript𝜁𝛼1superscript𝜁𝛼superscript𝜁2𝛼superscript1superscript𝜁𝛼2\Lambda\!\triangleq\!\frac{\zeta^{2\alpha}}{1-\zeta^{2\alpha}}\!+\!\frac{2\zeta^{\alpha}}{1-\zeta^{\alpha}}\!+\!\frac{\zeta^{2\alpha}}{(1-\zeta^{\alpha})^{2}}, V3≜τ1​τ2​(τ1​τ2​Λ+τ1​τ2−12​2−ζα1−ζα)≜subscript𝑉3subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2Λsubscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2122superscript𝜁𝛼1superscript𝜁𝛼V_{3}\triangleq\tau_{1}\tau_{2}\left(\tau_{1}\tau_{2}\Lambda+\frac{\tau_{1}\tau_{2}-1}{2}\frac{2-\zeta^{\alpha}}{1-\zeta^{\alpha}}\right), V1≜(τ1​τ2​ζ2​α1−ζ2​α+τ1​τ2−12)≜subscript𝑉1subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2superscript𝜁2𝛼1superscript𝜁2𝛼subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏212V_{1}\triangleq\left(\tau_{1}\tau_{2}\frac{\zeta^{2\alpha}}{1-\zeta^{2\alpha}}+\frac{\tau_{1}\tau_{2}-1}{2}\right) /(1−16​η2​L2​V3)absent116superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉3/(1-16\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{3}), and V2≜V3/(1−16​η2​L2​V3)≜subscript𝑉2subscript𝑉3116superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉3V_{2}\triangleq V_{3}/(1-16\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{3}).

Proof.  By using (10), we expand 𝐖k​(𝐈−𝐌)subscript𝐖𝑘𝐈𝐌\mathbf{W}_{\!k}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{M}) as 𝐖0​(𝐈−𝐌)​∏l=0k−1𝐓l−η​∑s=0k−1𝐆s​(∏l=sk−1𝐓l−𝐌)subscript𝐖0𝐈𝐌superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙0𝑘1subscript𝐓𝑙𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝑘1subscript𝐆𝑠superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙𝑠𝑘1subscript𝐓𝑙𝐌\mathbf{W}_{0}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{M})\prod_{l=0}^{k-1}\mathbf{T}_{l}-\eta\sum_{s=0}^{k-1}\mathbf{G}_{s}\left(\prod_{l=s}^{k-1}\mathbf{T}_{l}\!-\!\mathbf{M}\right). Since 𝒘0(i)=𝒘0,∀i∈𝒞formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒘0𝑖subscript𝒘0for-all𝑖𝒞\bm{w}_{0}^{(i)}=\bm{w}_{0},\forall i\in\mathcal{C}, (13) can be shown by bounding 𝔼​[‖η​∑s=0k−1𝐆s​(∏l=sk−1𝐓l−𝐌)‖𝐌2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝑘1subscript𝐆𝑠superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙𝑠𝑘1subscript𝐓𝑙𝐌𝐌2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\eta\sum_{s=0}^{k-1}\mathbf{G}_{s}\left(\prod_{l=s}^{k-1}\mathbf{T}_{l}-\mathbf{M}\right)\right\|_{\mathbf{M}}^{2}\right]. Please refer to Appendix A-C for the complete proof. □□\square

By substituting (11) in the RHS of (10) and choosing a proper learning rate to eliminate the term 1K​∑k=1KJk1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐽𝑘\frac{1}{K}\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}J_{k}, we are able to bound the expected average-square gradients in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

If the learning rate η𝜂\eta satisfies:

1−η​L−8​η2​L2​V2≥0,1−16​η2​L2​V3>0,formulae-sequence1𝜂𝐿8superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉20116superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉301-\eta L-8\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{2}\geq 0,1-16\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{3}>0, (14)

we have:

1K​∑k=1K𝔼​[‖∇F​(𝒖k)‖22]≤2​Δη​K+η​L​∑i∈𝒞mi2​σ2+2​η2​L2​V1​σ2+8​η2​L2​V2​κ2,1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒖𝑘222Δ𝜂𝐾𝜂𝐿subscript𝑖𝒞superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖2superscript𝜎22superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉1superscript𝜎28superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2subscript𝑉2superscript𝜅2\begin{split}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla F(\bm{u}_{k})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]&\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta K}+\eta L\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{C}}m_{i}^{2}\sigma^{2}\\ &+2\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{1}\sigma^{2}+8\eta^{2}L^{2}V_{2}\kappa^{2},\end{split} (15)

where Δ≜𝔼​[F​(𝐮1)]−𝔼​[F​(𝐮∗)]≜Δ𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐮1𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐮\Delta\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}_{1})\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}^{*})\right] and 𝐮∗≜arg⁡min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰)≜superscript𝐮subscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\bm{u}^{*}\triangleq\arg\min_{\bm{w}}F(\bm{w}).

Proof.  Please refer to the Appendix A-D. □□\square

With the results in Theorem 1, we are able to draw various insights as elaborated in the following remarks.

Remark 1.

It is straightforward that the RHS of (15) increases with both τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} and τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2}. Thus, it is preferable to choose τ1=τ2=1subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏21\tau_{1}=\tau_{2}=1 to reduce the number of training iterations without considering the training time. However, as will be seen in Section IV, performing either intra-cluster or inter-cluster model aggregations in the most frequent way turns out to be sub-optimal for the overall training latency.

Remark 2.

By taking the first-order derivative, we see that the RHS of (15) also increases with ζαsuperscript𝜁𝛼\zeta^{\alpha}, indicating that either increasing α𝛼\alpha (i.e., increasing the inter-server communication overhead) or decreasing ζ𝜁\zeta (i.e., increasing the degree of connectivity among the edge servers) results in faster convergence. For better illustration, three typical network topologies of six edge servers are shown in Fig. 2, including the ring, partially connected and fully connected topologies, and the values of ζ𝜁\zeta are given as 0.6, 0.333 and 0, respectively. In other words, the fully-connected network topology achieves the best performance. Besides, in the extreme case with α→∞→𝛼\alpha\!\rightarrow\!\infty, the edge servers can reach consensus after inter-cluster model aggregation (i.e., 𝒘~k(d)←∑j∈𝒟|𝒮~j||𝒮|​𝒘~k(j)←superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑑subscript𝑗𝒟subscript~𝒮𝑗𝒮superscriptsubscript~𝒘𝑘𝑗\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(d)}\!\leftarrow\!\sum_{j\in\mathcal{D}}\frac{|\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{j}|}{|\mathcal{S}|}\tilde{\bm{w}}_{k}^{(j)}) even with a sparsely connected network.

Remark 3.

When τ1=1subscript𝜏11\tau_{1}=1, τ2=1subscript𝜏21\tau_{2}=1, and ζα=0superscript𝜁𝛼0\zeta^{\alpha}=0, i.e., the local models of all the client nodes are synchronized at each iteration, the convergence result in Theorem 1 reduces to that of the fully synchronous SGD algorithm [18]. In addition, when κ=0𝜅0\kappa=0, i.e., in the IID case, our result also improves over that obtained in [15].

IV Experiments

IV-A Settings

We simulate an SD-FEEL system with 50 client nodes and 10 edge servers, and each edge server is associated with five client nodes. In our experiments, we consider a ring topology of the edge servers as shown in Fig. 2(a) unless otherwise specified.

SD-FEEL is evaluated on the CIFAR-10 dataset, which is a benchmark dataset for image classification tasks containing 10 categories of images. To simulate the non-IID data distribution, we follow [19] by allocating a proportion pl,jsubscript𝑝𝑙𝑗p_{l,j} of the training samples of class l𝑙l to the j𝑗j-th client node, where pl,jsubscript𝑝𝑙𝑗p_{l,j} is sampled from a Dirichlet distribution Dir50​(0.5)subscriptDir500.5\text{Dir}_{50}(0.5). We use a convolutional neural network with two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers that consists of 21,840 trainable parameters [12]. The batch size and the learning rate of mini-batch SGD are set as 10 and 0.01, respectively.

To verify the effectiveness of SD-FEEL in reducing training latency, we adopt the following FL schemes for comparisons:

  • •

    FedAvg [3]: This is a Cloud-based FL scheme, where a Cloud-based PS collects and aggregates models from all client nodes after every τ=τ1​τ2𝜏subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2\tau\!=\!\tau_{1}\tau_{2} local model updates.

  • •

    FEEL [7]: This is a conventional edge-assisted FL scheme, where an edge server randomly schedules five client nodes at each iteration due to the limited number of wireless channels. Note that this is consistent with the number of accessible client nodes for each edge server in SD-FEEL.

  • •

    HierFAVG [12]: This FL scheme leverages a Cloud-based PS and multiple edge servers. Specifically, the edge servers perform local model aggregation after every τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} local updates; whereas the Cloud-based PS aggregates models from the edge servers after every τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} local model aggregations.

IV-B Training Latency Calculation

For SD-FEEL, the latency of the K𝐾K training iterations is calculated as ttot=⌈Kτ1​τ2⌉​[τ2​(τ1​tcmpct+tcmmct-sr)+α​tcmmsr-sr]subscript𝑡tot𝐾subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2delimited-[]subscript𝜏2subscript𝜏1superscriptsubscript𝑡cmpctsuperscriptsubscript𝑡cmmct-sr𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑡cmmsr-srt_{\text{tot}}\!=\!\left\lceil\frac{K}{\tau_{1}\tau_{2}}\right\rceil\left[\tau_{2}(\tau_{1}t_{\text{cmp}}^{\text{ct}}+t_{\text{cmm}}^{\text{ct-sr}})+\alpha t_{\text{cmm}}^{\text{sr-sr}}\right], where tcmpctsuperscriptsubscript𝑡cmpctt_{\text{cmp}}^{\text{ct}} denotes the computation latency for each local update, tcmmct-srsuperscriptsubscript𝑡cmmct-srt_{\text{cmm}}^{\text{ct-sr}} denotes the model uploading latency between a client node and its associated edge server, and tcmmsr-srsuperscriptsubscript𝑡cmmsr-srt_{\text{cmm}}^{\text{sr-sr}} is the model transmission latency between neighboring edge servers. We assume tcmpct=NMACCCPUsuperscriptsubscript𝑡cmpctsubscript𝑁MACsubscript𝐶CPUt_{\text{cmp}}^{\text{ct}}\!=\!\frac{N_{\text{MAC}}}{C_{\text{CPU}}}, where NMAC=138.4​MFLOPssubscript𝑁MAC138.4MFLOPsN_{\text{MAC}}\!=\!138.4\,\text{MFLOPs} is the number of the floating-point operations (FLOPs) required for each local iteration111The number of FLOPs required for local training at each iteration is calculated using OpCounter, which is an open-source model analysis library available at https://github.com/Lyken17/pytorch-OpCounter., and CCPU=10​GFLOPSsubscript𝐶CPU10GFLOPSC_{\text{CPU}}\!=\!10\,\text{GFLOPS} denotes the computing bandwidth of the local processors. The communication latency is expressed as tcmm=MbitRsubscript𝑡cmmsubscript𝑀bit𝑅t_{\text{cmm}}\!=\!\frac{M_{\rm{bit}}}{R} with Mbit=32​M​bitssubscript𝑀bit32𝑀bitsM_{\rm{bit}}\!=\!32M\,\text{bits} and R𝑅R denoting the transmission rate. Specifically, we assume that the client nodes communicate with the associated edge servers using orthogonal channels and there is no inter-cluster interference [20]. The transmission rate is assumed to be Rct-sr=B​log2⁡(1+SNR)≈5​Mbpssuperscript𝑅ct-sr𝐵subscript21SNR5MbpsR^{\text{ct-sr}}\!=\!B\log_{2}{(1+\text{SNR}})\!\approx\!5\,\text{Mbps}, where B=1​MHz𝐵1MHzB\!=\!1\,\text{MHz} and SNR=15​dBSNR15dB\text{SNR}\!=\!15\,\text{dB}. The edge server communicates with the neighboring edge servers via high-speed links with the bandwidth of 50​Mbps50Mbps50\,\text{Mbps} [21], and the bandwidth from the edge servers to the Cloud is set as 5​Mbps5Mbps5\,\text{Mbps}. Accordingly, the transmission rate from the client nodes to the Cloud is given by Rct-cd=2.5​Mbpssuperscript𝑅ct-cd2.5MbpsR^{\text{ct-cd}}\!=\!2.5\,\text{Mbps}.

IV-C Results

IV-C1 Convergence Speed and Learning Performance

We show the training loss and test accuracy over time in Fig. 3(a) and Fig. 3(b), respectively. It can be observed that, the training loss of SD-FEEL drops rapidly at the early stage of the training process, and converges at around 250 minutes. Comparatively, the training progress of FedAvg lags far behind due to slow model uploading from the client nodes to the Cloud-based PS in each iteration. On the other hand, due to infrequent communications to the Cloud, HierFAVG also converges within 250 minutes. However, it suffers higher training loss compared to SD-FEEL since the communication among edge servers in SD-FEEL is more efficient and thus accelerates the learning progress. It is also worthwhile to note that, although FEEL enjoys a low uplink transmission delay, the limited number of accessible client nodes results in an unstable training process and thus leads to much higher training loss. This demonstrates the effectiveness of SD-FEEL in achieving fast convergence by removing the reliance on the Cloud-based infrastructure. From Fig. 3(b), it is seen that SD-FEEL secures test accuracy improvement compared to HierFAVG, while the learned models of FedAvg and FEEL within the given training time are simply unusable.

IV-C2 Ablation Study

We investigate the impacts of the intra-cluster model aggregation period τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} by showing the relationship between training loss and iterations (training latency) in Fig. 4(a) (Fig. 4(b)). For both figures, we fix τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} to 1 and evaluate the configurations with τ1=1,3,and​ 20subscript𝜏113and20\tau_{1}\!=\!1,3,\,\text{and}\,20. From Fig. 4(a) we observe that a smaller value of τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} leads to a lower training loss within a given number of training iterations, as discussed in Remark 1. However, this conclusion becomes invalid in terms of training latency as shown in Fig. 4(b), where τ1=3subscript𝜏13\tau_{1}\!=\!3 achieves the minimum training loss. This is owing to the fact that less frequent intra-cluster model aggregations help to save communication time. Similar behaviors can be observed by varying τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} with a given value of τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}. We omit the results here due to the limited space. These observations jointly necessitate an optimal choice of the intra-/inter-cluster model aggregation frequencies for the minimum training latency.

We also evaluate the test accuracy of SD-FEEL on different network topologies of the edge servers. As shown in Fig. 5(a), we see that within a given number of training iterations, a more connected network topology achieves a higher test accuracy, since more information is collected from neighboring edge clusters in each round of inter-server model aggregation, as explained in Remark 2. Besides, effects of α𝛼\alpha on the test accuracy are examined via a ring topology in Fig. 5(b). In line with Remark 2, a larger value of α𝛼\alpha increases the training speed in terms of iterations. It is also observed that when α𝛼\alpha is greater than 10, the test accuracy approaches the case with a fully-connected network, and further increasing α𝛼\alpha brings marginal improvement. Therefore, based on the network topology of edge servers, we can choose a suitable value of α𝛼\alpha to balance the communication cost and learning performance.

We further evaluate SD-FEEL with probabilistic dropout of the client nodes in Fig. 6, where a client node participates the training process with a certain probability, denoted as β𝛽\beta, in each round. It is observed that SD-FEEL still maintains the convergence behavior with a reasonable amount of dropout client nodes, despite experiences slight degradation of the learned model accuracy. We leave the thorough investigation on SD-FEEL with partial participation to our further works.

V Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated a novel FL architecture, namely semi-decentralized federated edge learning (SD-FEEL), to realize low-latency distributed learning on non-IID data. Convergence analysis was conducted for the training algorithm of SD-FEEL, from which, various insights were drawn for system implementation. Simulations demonstrated that SD-FEEL substantially reduces the training latency while improving the learning performance. For future works, it is worth investigating the optimal intra-cluster and inter-cluster model aggregation frequencies and analyzing the convergence of SD-FEEL with partial participation. It would also be interesting to consider more practical scenarios with device heterogeneity.

A-B Lemmas

Lemma 3.

The eigenvalues of 𝐇1subscript𝐇1\mathbf{H}_{1} and 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} have the following properties:

  • •

    𝐇1subscript𝐇1\mathbf{H}_{1} has a left eigenvector 𝟏Tsuperscript1𝑇\bm{1}^{T} with eigenvalue 1, and a right eigenvector 𝒎𝒎\bm{m} with eigenvalue 1.

  • •

    𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} has a left eigenvector 𝟏Tsuperscript1𝑇\bm{1}^{T} with eigenvalue 1, and a right eigenvector 𝒎𝒎\bm{m} with eigenvalue 1.

  • •

    The eigenvalues of 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} are same as the eigenvalues of 𝐏αsuperscript𝐏𝛼\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}, and the absolute values of all the eigenvalues except the largest one are no greater than 1.

Proof.  Since when α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} reduces to 𝐇1subscript𝐇1\mathbf{H}_{1}, it suffices to prove the first and second properties for 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} for arbitrary α𝛼\alpha. Denote the associated edge server of client node i𝑖i as d​(i)𝑑𝑖d(i). According to the definition of 𝐇2≜[h2i,j]≜subscript𝐇2delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptℎ2𝑖𝑗\mathbf{H}_{2}\triangleq[h_{2}^{i,j}], we have:

h2i,j=∑d′(∑dvi,d​pαd,d′)​bd′,j​=(a)​vi,d​(i)​pαd​(i),d​(j)​bd​(j),j=m^i​pαd​(i),d​(j),superscriptsubscriptℎ2𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑑′subscript𝑑superscript𝑣𝑖𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑superscript𝑑′superscript𝑏superscript𝑑′𝑗(a)superscript𝑣𝑖𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑𝑖𝑑𝑗superscript𝑏𝑑𝑗𝑗subscript^𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑𝑖𝑑𝑗h_{2}^{i,j}=\sum_{d^{\prime}}(\sum_{d}v^{i,d}p_{\alpha}^{d,d^{\prime}})b^{d^{\prime},j}\overset{\text{(a)}}{=}v^{i,d(i)}p_{\alpha}^{d(i),d(j)}b^{d(j),j}=\hat{m}_{i}p_{\alpha}^{d(i),d(j)}, (16)

where pαd,d′superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑superscript𝑑′p_{\alpha}^{d,d^{\prime}} denotes the element in d𝑑d-th row and d′superscript𝑑′d^{\prime}-th column of 𝐏αsuperscript𝐏𝛼\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}, (a) holds since vi,d=m^i​𝟙​{i∈𝒞d}superscript𝑣𝑖𝑑subscript^𝑚𝑖1𝑖subscript𝒞𝑑v^{i,d}=\hat{m}_{i}\mathbbm{1}\left\{i\in\mathcal{C}_{d}\right\} and bd,i=𝟙​{i∈𝒞d}superscript𝑏𝑑𝑖1𝑖subscript𝒞𝑑b^{d,i}=\mathbbm{1}\left\{i\in\mathcal{C}_{d}\right\}. Since ∑ih2i,j=∑d∈𝒟(∑i∈𝒞dm^i​pαd​(i),d​(j))=∑d∈𝒟pαd,d′=1subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ2𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝒟subscript𝑖subscript𝒞𝑑subscript^𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑𝑖𝑑𝑗subscript𝑑𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑superscript𝑑′1\sum_{i}h_{2}^{i,j}=\sum_{d\in\mathcal{D}}(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{d}}\hat{m}_{i}p_{\alpha}^{d(i),d(j)})=\sum_{d\in\mathcal{D}}p_{\alpha}^{d,d^{\prime}}=1, it is easy to verify that 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} has a left eigenvector 𝟏Tsuperscript1𝑇\bm{1}^{T} with eigenvalue 1. Similarly, since ∑jh2i,j​mj=m^i​(∑jpαd​(i),d​(j)​mj)=m^isubscript𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ2𝑖𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗subscript^𝑚𝑖subscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝛼𝑑𝑖𝑑𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗subscript^𝑚𝑖\sum_{j}h_{2}^{i,j}m_{j}=\hat{m}_{i}(\sum_{j}p_{\alpha}^{d(i),d(j)}m_{j})=\hat{m}_{i}, 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} has a right eigenvector 𝒎𝒎\bm{m} with eigenvalue 1.

By invoking Proposition 2 of [15], it can be shown that the non-zero eigenvalues of 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} are same as those of 𝐏αsuperscript𝐏𝛼\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}. Since 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is doubly stochastic, i.e., it satisfies 𝐏T=𝐏superscript𝐏𝑇𝐏\mathbf{P}^{T}=\mathbf{P} and 𝐏​𝟏=𝟏𝐏11\mathbf{P}\bm{1}=\bm{1}, the D𝐷D eigenvalues satisfy 1=|λ1​(𝐏)|>|λ2​(𝐏)|≥⋯≥|λD​(𝐏)|≥01subscript𝜆1𝐏subscript𝜆2𝐏⋯subscript𝜆𝐷𝐏01=|\lambda_{1}(\mathbf{P})|>|\lambda_{2}(\mathbf{P})|\geq\dots\geq|\lambda_{D}(\mathbf{P})|\geq 0. Because λi​(𝐏α)=λiα​(𝐏),i=1,⋯,Dformulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑖superscript𝐏𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝛼𝐏𝑖1⋯𝐷\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\right)=\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{P}\right),i=1,\cdots,D, we have 1=|λ1​(𝐏α)|>|λ2​(𝐏α)|≥⋯≥|λD​(𝐏α)|≥01subscript𝜆1superscript𝐏𝛼subscript𝜆2superscript𝐏𝛼⋯subscript𝜆𝐷superscript𝐏𝛼01=\left|\lambda_{1}\left(\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\right)\right|>\left|\lambda_{2}\left(\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\right)\right|\geq\dots\geq\left|\lambda_{D}\left(\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\right)\right|\geq 0. □□\square

Lemma 4.

Matrix 𝐓ksubscript𝐓𝑘\mathbf{T}_{k} in (11) satisfies 𝐓k​𝐌=𝐌𝐓k=𝐌subscript𝐓𝑘𝐌subscript𝐌𝐓𝑘𝐌\mathbf{T}_{k}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{T}_{k}=\mathbf{M}.

Proof.  We show this lemma by analyzing the three cases of (11) respectively. For the first case, we have 𝐓k​𝐌=𝐕𝐁𝐌=𝐇1​𝒎​𝟏T=𝒎​𝟏T=𝐌subscript𝐓𝑘𝐌𝐕𝐁𝐌subscript𝐇1𝒎superscript1𝑇𝒎superscript1𝑇𝐌\mathbf{T}_{k}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{V}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{H}_{1}\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\mathbf{M}, and 𝐌𝐓k=𝐌𝐕𝐁=𝒎​𝟏T​𝐇1=𝒎​𝟏T=𝐌subscript𝐌𝐓𝑘𝐌𝐕𝐁𝒎superscript1𝑇subscript𝐇1𝒎superscript1𝑇𝐌\mathbf{M}\mathbf{T}_{k}=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{V}\mathbf{B}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}\mathbf{H}_{1}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\mathbf{M}. For the second case, we have 𝐓k​𝐌=𝐕𝐏α​𝐁𝐌=𝐇2​𝒎​𝟏T=𝒎​𝟏T=𝐌subscript𝐓𝑘𝐌superscript𝐕𝐏𝛼𝐁𝐌subscript𝐇2𝒎superscript1𝑇𝒎superscript1𝑇𝐌\mathbf{T}_{k}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{V}\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{H}_{2}\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\mathbf{M}, and 𝐌𝐓k=𝐌𝐕𝐏α​𝐁=𝒎​𝟏T​𝐇2=𝒎​𝟏T=𝐌subscript𝐌𝐓𝑘superscript𝐌𝐕𝐏𝛼𝐁𝒎superscript1𝑇subscript𝐇2𝒎superscript1𝑇𝐌\mathbf{M}\mathbf{T}_{k}=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{V}\mathbf{P}^{\alpha}\mathbf{B}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}\mathbf{H}_{2}=\bm{m}\bm{1}^{T}=\mathbf{M}. Moreover, the third case can be shown by similar arguments, i.e. 𝐓k​𝐌=𝐈𝐌=𝐌subscript𝐓𝑘𝐌𝐈𝐌𝐌\mathbf{T}_{k}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{I}\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{M} and 𝐌𝐓k=𝐌𝐈=𝐌subscript𝐌𝐓𝑘𝐌𝐈𝐌\mathbf{M}\mathbf{T}_{k}=\mathbf{M}\mathbf{I}=\mathbf{M}. □□\square

Lemma 6.

𝐇1subscript𝐇1\mathbf{H}_{1} and 𝐇2subscript𝐇2\mathbf{H}_{2} have the following properties:

‖𝐇1−𝐌‖op=1,subscriptnormsubscript𝐇1𝐌op1\displaystyle\left\|\mathbf{H}_{1}-\mathbf{M}\right\|_{\mathrm{op}}=1, (20)

where ∥⋅∥op≜max‖𝐰‖=1𝐗𝐰=λmax​(𝐗T​𝐗)\left\|\cdot\right\|_{\mathrm{op}}\triangleq\max_{\left\|\bm{w}\right\|=1}\mathbf{X}\bm{w}=\sqrt{\lambda_{\mathrm{max}}(\mathbf{X}^{T}\mathbf{X})} denotes the operator norm.

Proof.  According to Lemma 3 and the definition of the matrix operation norm, we have:

‖𝐇2j−𝐌‖op=λmax​((𝐇2j−𝐌)T​(𝐇2j−𝐌))=λmax​(𝐇22​j−𝐌2)=λmax​(𝐇1−𝐌)2​j=ζj​α.subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝐇2𝑗𝐌opsubscript𝜆superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐇2𝑗𝐌𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐇2𝑗𝐌subscript𝜆superscriptsubscript𝐇22𝑗superscript𝐌2subscript𝜆superscriptsubscript𝐇1𝐌2𝑗superscript𝜁𝑗𝛼\begin{split}\left\|\mathbf{H}_{2}^{j}-\mathbf{M}\right\|_{\text{op}}=\sqrt{\lambda_{\max}((\mathbf{H}_{2}^{j}-\mathbf{M})^{T}(\mathbf{H}_{2}^{j}-\mathbf{M}))}=\sqrt{\lambda_{\max}(\mathbf{H}_{2}^{2j}-\mathbf{M}^{2})}=\sqrt{\lambda_{\max}(\mathbf{H}_{1}-\mathbf{M})^{2j}}=\zeta^{j\alpha}.\end{split} (22)

Lemma 7.

A-D Proof of Theorem 1

First, we sum up (17) in Lemma 5 for k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K, and divide both sides by K𝐾K as follows:
